review_body: I was staying at the hotel for 2 nights with the Hong Kong Rugby League Team for our game against Japan. We were welcomed with drinks and snacks, cheered by the Moxy team and upon our return from the rugby match, there were pictures of our win all over the hotel but also all over our guest rooms each personalized with a nice little note. Big up to Anne, the Director of Operations of the hotel as well as her lovely team for going the extra mile for us. I believe you all placed us in great conditions to win. Fantastic service, great location direct to Narita, nice bars around. I immediately felt at home from the start and would recommend anyone going to Tokyo to stay there. Anne, thank you, you and your team made such a impact and a difference. We were all impressed and certainly didn't expect all of this. My hats off. Until next time. Cy, thanks to you as well for all you did. You made the logistics a lot more simple and looked after us all the way. Ben and the HK Rugby League team

If you are traveling to anywhere near the Tokyo Sky tree then this is a great stylish hotel to stay at. It is in a very Japanese area (aka not touristy) but the staff is great and they speak English fluently. The rooms are modern and have full size facilities so you won't feel cramped. The bar and breakfast are right in the lobby and very reasonable. Japan can get expensive so this is a nice option and it does not feel cheap at all. The area has some "adult" areas around it but it feels completely safe and it would be fine to bring kids to. The best part is the staff and they great you with a complimentary drink and have great advice about where to eat and other activities.

I’m the Chairman of Hong Kong Rugby League, we decided to stay here for our game against Japan and we couldn’t have been happier. The hotel staff were simply fantastic and went well out of their way to look after us, they put on welcome drinks and food, after game photos and incredibly put photos of the game on our doors so when we came back and on our beds. Brilliant customer service. The rooms were also great.

What a concept!! A relaIvely inexpensive stay, a large comfortable bed, large tv, walk-in shower with a “rain” option and a 4 Star buffet breakfast included in the room. The location is a “bit on the edge” as is the concept for this surprising Marriott property. Go for it for a new hotel experience!!

Exactly as pictured - This hotel actually looks exactly like their promotional photos which is rare. Decor is cute & modern. Cleanliness - Super clean, everywhere you look including public areas. Hotel sheets and towels are bright white, looked brand new.Rooms - While the rooms are tiny (typical for Tokyo), they are very functional. That’s right, not even a closet; they have pegs on the wall and a cabinet. We made it work. Super comfy bed, like a cloud. The room rates are very reasonable but keep in mind we had to get 2 rooms for 4 people (this will apply to a lot of other hotels too).Staff - Every person we talked to was helpful, polite and professional. I was worried about the bar checkin (we’re a family of 4) and the loud DJ parties. Don’t worry, in fact it was one of the most efficient checkins I’ve ever experienced. After we checked out the hotel called me thinking I forgot something but it was another guest’s.Here’s why I took off a star:Breakfast - The breakfast is actually a good value for the cost (we added it to our room rate via Expedia @$8 PP). It included the Japanese staples, mini waffles & pancakes (these were not refilled often), yummy breads, fruit, yogurt, good coffee and a variety of juices. The issue is that while breakfast hours are 6:30 AM - 10:30 AM, there’s almost nothing left, not even cups starting around 9:30 AM. That’s unacceptable.Safe - There was no safe in the room which meant I was walking around with our passports all day in my handbag.Location - First, hotel is literally 3 blocks from the metro & JR station. While it’s not right in the more touristy areas, it’s very convenient to Disney so it was a good compromise. Across the street from our side of the hotel there is a convenience store and every other night, there was such a LOUD group hanging out there for hours. Not the hotel’s fault, but something to consider.

Moxy Kinshicho is close to popular tourist areas such as Tokyo Skytree, Kokugikan and the Kameido Tenjin Shrine. It is about a 6-7 minute walk from Kinshicho Station, a major JR station. Do not be put off by its location, right in the midst of a rather seedy part of Tokyo. (There are lots of solicitors hoping to lure male customers; they will not bother women or male-female couples.).The guest rooms tend to be on the smallish side but the bathroom has a reasonably sized shower with great water pressure. To make up for the lack of space in the room, there are plenty of public spaces — the bar/cafe , living room area and library. The 24 hour fitness room in the basement has all the equipment for a basic workout. There is a laundromat on the same floor.The breakfast does not offer much variety but the quality was very good. I was actually glad I chose the rate that came with breakfast due to the scarcity of places offering breakfast within the vicinity of the hotel. One of Tokyo’s ubiquitous convenience stores is located across the street. Lots of local eateries can be found around Kinshicho station. We found a nice little wine bar offering happy hour drinks and a delicious place featuring Japanese oden.Last but not least, the staff at Moxy are efficient, courteous and friendly. I love the idea that the check in counter is also the bar!

Moxy hotel is not a usual Marriott hotel but a new concept of Marriott hotel. Far more modern and cheaper. Check-in/out at the bar. Big lounge where everyone can work, drink, eat nibbles, play games... Library at the back for quieter work. Lockers, fitness room, ironing room. Always free daily fresh water and hot water for tea. Japanese and Western Buffet breakfast. Noodles for lunch. No restaurant for diner but there are salads, hot-dogs, flat breads, yoghurts...If not enough there is a Mini Stop shop in front of the hotel, otherwise a huge choice of Japanese restaurants around. The room is enough for 2. Nice modern and cosy room. Very confortable bed. Air conditioning available. Everything you need is provided. Big TV screen. The Moxy is close to Kinshicho station, very useful and easy to get to the various districts of Tokyo. The area is safe. The staff is welcoming, friendly and efficient. Live DJ week-ends and Nintendo video games!

Stayed at this place for 1 night in early May prior to leaving Osaka. I checked in early and, to my surprise, I was given a room right away. I was also provided a welcome drink which was pretty nice. The room was nice and clean. This time around I didn't have the experience of housekeeping throwing away my toothbrush and razor as I only stayed for 1 night. I got plenty of work done in the lobby area where there was a long table with plenty of electrical outlets to connect your various devices. I've read previous reviews that this hotel is in the red light district. Though this may be true, I don't think the rating of this place should go down because of that. If they had time to make the review, then they had time to research the area too. All in all, a great place to stay with walking distance to the Kinshicho station. Plus it's just one stop to the Sumo stadium Ryogoku Kokugikan.

The staff are cool yet friendly and helpful, they are always willing to help. The design of the hotel is cool with a lot of entertainment such as TV games and free for customer to use, despite the hotel is located near the bar and club area. You would hear the noise from the drunk people on street in room but I think it’s a minor issue. It’s safe to walk on the street at night from the station to the hotel. The room is clean and strategically design, not very big but fully use the space in it. The DJ in the lobby is a plus as well. No mini fridge in room, not so convenient. Strongly recommend this hotel and would stay there again if I visit Tokyo again.

The hotel was so comfortable!I lent "Japanese Kimono"at a parlor near the hotel to visit Asakusa city.The parlor was kind and they arrange my hair beautifully.I think the place of the hotel is also nice.

Moxy Tokyo Kinshicho is good for young ppl. It’s more like American style hotel than we stayed in others. We impressed that we check in at the bar. It’s interesting. The front desk speaks multi-languages and seems nice to guests. Breakfast offers ramen, and some usual western style food. The location of hotel is near JR/Tokyo metro. It’s quick and easy to access other places. Some man in the street in night and they did not bother us if we say no. You may have your friends with you in the night if you do not feel comfortable for this.Our card-key turned to invalid when we went back to hotel in 14:00 o’clock although we notified front desk that we needed late check out while we check in.We are satisfy with in high floor room.

The hotel is modern. The rooms are stylish and have a good amount of space for Tokyo. Great fitness center and laundry. The metro is a short walk away. The neighborhood is funky but safe. Many small restaurants. A reasonable walk is to the large sky tower complex. The staff are very helpful and friendly. Breakfast was very good. Japanese and US type foods are available.

位置很好，但往火車站的街道上有一些成人俱樂部。 我認為這對女性顧客來說是危險的。酒店沒有冰箱，有點不方便。幾乎所有的員工都充滿熱情！ 然而，有個女性工作人員的態度非常糟糕！她總是把不開心的臉給我們看，她的服務真的很糟糕！ （她總是白天工作，黑色長髮，在官方視頻中的最後幾個場景有出現，可能是日本人？）順便說一下，面向高速公路的房間有點吵！The location is good, but there are some adult clubs on the street to the train station. I think that it is kind of dangerous to female customers. The hotel doesn't have refrigerator, and it's somewhat inconvenient. Almost all the staff with passion! However, one of your female staff's attitude was really bad! She always put her sad face to us, and her service was really terrible! (She is always at day-time duty, black with long hair, showing at the official video at last few scenes, maybe Japanese?)By the way, the room facing to the highway was a little noisy!

The Moxy is not necessarily for first time visitors to Tokyo. First time visitors will probably be turned off about the Kinshicho area. It's not touristy, it's local. No one here will make a big deal of you, Mr and Mrs Western Tourist. Walking to the hotel is a challenge of your ability to read a map. Here's the easy way. Walk out of the train station, through the plaza, toward the main street. Turn right down the main street. When you come across a 7-11, turn left and walk down three blocks. The hotel is across the street from a Mini-Stop. There. You've just navigated like a local. And the area you walked through is full of yakatori bars, restaurants, clubs and bars. And contrary to some of the reviews posted here, just because there are young and attractive women hawking for bars and clubs DOES NOT MAKE THEM PROSTITUTES. Once you get to the hotel, the first question is "where is the front desk"? You enter the hotel and on the right is a lounge area and the left is the bar and tables. Go to the bar and check in. Also get yourself a drink or a snack. I recommend the wall o'instant noodles. Breakfast is also served here. The staff here is different from other western hotel chains. The Moxy took great pains to hire staff who are fluent in English and have a personality. Excellent! Despite this being part of Marriott, this is NOT a full service hotel. Think of this as more of a business hotel with an edge. If you want water, drink out of the tap. If you want it in a bottle, run across the street to Mini Stop. This isn't a typical western hotel where you can gorge yourself on lounge food and take home a dozen water bottles. You'll see what I mean about business hotels when you see the room. The rooms are decorated well, with a combination of wood and industrial style. There is no closet but rather there are hangers on the wall. Along with a chair and folding table. And the TV. The beds are excellently firm and have warm poofy duvets (I visited last December as winter was arriving). Unlike Japanese business hotels with their plastic bathrooms, the bathrooms here were nice, The rooms here are roomy for one, crowded for two. If you're here with a significant other, it's fine. If you're here with a travel buddy, you'll want to get separate rooms. It's that tight. The staff was fantastic in accommodating us when we decided that we needed a second room. Easy peasy which it isn't always in Tokyo. And one of the staff, Kei (who spent time in Georgia during University) went out of his way to walk the two of us to an excellent yakuniku place near the train station. He didn't have to but he did. Thanks! The Moxy has a lot of things going for it for experienced travelers. Regular Tokyo visitors don't necessarily need to be in the heart of it. Roppongi, Shinjuku and Shibuya are great spots to hang out in but have ridiculously expensive lodging. At the same time, if you've been to Tokyo before, you don't have to subject yourself to the backpacker ghetto in Taito-Ku either. The Moxy is close to a major train station, there's local places to eat and hang out, it's staffed by fun and knowledgeable Edokko and there's a coin laundry in the basement. Just thought I'd mention that last bit, because that's where you'll meet fellow travelers.

I stayed here with my wife for two nights at the start of our week in Japan - we are Marriott Platinum and were a little apprehensive about the Moxy brand, as we are used to full service hotels - the apprehension was entirely groundless. We flew into Narita and got the Narita Express to Tokyo, then back-tracked along the same line the short distance to Kinshicho station. If you have a Japan rail pass, make sure you get the JR train to Kinshicho, as it is included in the scheme.From the station, it is s short, easy walk to the hotel. We were a little early, it was only 1300, we checked in okay and were given a very nice room 1002 on the top floor of 10. We were also given some free drinks vouchers and four breakfast vouchers for our two day stay. Moxy hotels are a fairly new concept, allegedly ‘trendy’ and designed for millennials, but are a lot cheaper than the traditional full service Marriotts, or even the Courtyards. We were a little unsure what to expect because Tokyo is renowned for its small hotel rooms. I have to say we were very impressed; the room has a big bed and a large bathroom with shower, lots of plug points and nice touches like amenity kits, water and slippers. There are collapsible chairs, luggage rack and a table hung on the wall to maximise space and even the phone is an old fashioned, push button quirky thing. Another nice touch is a motion activated light under the bed that gives a bit of light if you need to get up in the night. The area around the hotel could probably best be described as a 'Red Light' area with lots of clubs and other adult venues. This didn't cause us the slightest problem - there was no noise pollution from the clubs, and none of the 'adult activities' impacted on us in any way. Breakfast is buffet style with tin mugs, plates and utensils. They had sausage, eggs and bacon plus ramen done to order, as well as granola, yoghurt and fruit.The staff we encountered all seemed to fit the young and trendy demographic, but were all very helpful and friendly.There are lots of restaurants, bars and shops in the immediate area, and the proximity to Kinshicho station makes it a perfect base for any visitor to Tokyo.We recommend the hotel wholeheartedly , and will certainly return next time we are in Tokyo.

First time in Japan and it was a good place to stay; not too far from downtown and places to visit; the FD guys did a pretty good job with the check in and with recommendations when they were needed; the breakfast was good and most of the stuff were always helpful.

My Husband and I traveled to Tokyo and decided to stay at the Moxy for the first time. We had a fabulous time and the “crew” really looked after us. Anne and Kei in particular helped us to sort out our trip. Great staff and great hotel! Value for money, close to the train station! Thank you all!

Stayed in Tokyo almost two weeks, but at this hotel only one night. The hotel was a short walk to the train station and close by to cafes restaurants. Surprisingly a few streets around the hotel seemed a bit dirty with trash... which was a shock having spent the past two weeks seeing so much of the city and no trash prior was to be seen elsewhere! Not a biggie, however it stood out to me! Staff was friendly, layout and lobby was neat and seemed geared to a younger crowd. Although I’m young I felt like I was a little too uncool to stay here. Hehe! Room was comfy, petite, but spotless! Loved my stay, and would recommend to others!

Really enjoyed this hotel. Only 9 mins from Tokyo main station and a breeze to get to. Rooms are well presented, although a bit small, and the breakfast is great value. Tokyo is a super expensive place so it was a pleasure to stay somewhere that wasn't over the top. Very friendly staff...nothing too much trouble. Will be back.

Very relaxed and comfortable hotel, great and very friendly staff, rooms are nice and clean, close to train station just a casaul 5minute walk with a variety of eating places along the way, breakfast had a good seletion could do with a larger toaster though...

We stayed here during our first 4 nights in Tokyo. It was a really nice, eclectic hotel with a fun atmosphere. The hotel staff was very personable, helpful, nice and even remembered us during our stay. The train station was about a 5 min walk to/from hotel, which was very convenient. The bar also had great drink specials

The Moxy has a bright and modern feel about it - staff are young and friendly as well as very helpful. The hotel is located conveniently close to Kinshicho station which is a plus. Unfortunately it is also located in a less than savoury part of town - there are many "girls bars" and at night the surrounding streets are quite busy with this type of commercial activity. The hotel itself is well appointed and the rooms are very nice, although quite small - probably not ideal for international travellers wanting to place larger luggage in the room (we managed but it was squeezy). The other negative was that the room did not have a refrigerator and there were no tea making facilities . Overall we enjoyed our stay at The Moxy but there were some negatives that should be considered.

Location very convenient to sights and shopping. Very congenial atmosphere, excellent service and the rooms, while small, were perfectly adequate for a shorter stay.The reception and bar area is all one large well appointed area, including a comfortable sitting and play area. Good breakfast including and excellent bar food available. Staff very friendly and helpful. Would go back without question.

Moxy Tokyo Kinshicho exudes a fun and playful vibe to a modest and clean Tokyo hotel room. Location. 4.5/5. It is just a 10 minute walk from a major train station. The station also has direct trains to Narita airport, just google the exact line/ schedule. Convenience stores, malls and restaurants are within walking distance. A bit of a red-light district in the area. Check-in / Check-out. 4.5/5 No major problems. Counter was on the bar. Room. 4/5 We encountered a minor problem on our initial room i.e. broken TV. But it was resolved immediately. Rooms were refreshed daily. Toiletries were available. Size was a bit cozy, but it was adequate. Considering it was Tokyo, it was worth it. We stayed mostly outside anyway to explore the city. Amenities. 4/5 Ironing room per floor. Lockers and storage on the ground floor. Gym in the basement. Work / lounge area on the ground floor. Internet/ WiFi. 4.5/5 Service. 4/5 Money's worth. 4/5 Overall, a great stay in Moxy Tokyo. We would likely return in the future.

Conveniently close to the Kinshicho station which is three stops to Tokyo station on the subway. The reception is at the bar; you check in at the bar, which is OK during daytime. At night when there is loud music in the background, it becomes difficult to communicate with the front desk. The staff at the reception was very pleasant and helpful. The room was spacious, but there were no closets. We hanged our clothes on pegs on the wall. It was a 10 day stay and I could use a few drawers. You have to live by your suitcase, which is fine for a short stay. The room was clean. A coffee maker was not available in the room, so we asked for a kettle. They provided one immediately. Although we did not use it, there was a laundry machine and an ironing room available in the hotel. We did not spend much time at the hotel during the day, but realized that it got quite noisy during late night as too much was going around in the street below. I recommend this hotel to young couples, but not to families with children.

I’ll start by saying I work for one of Japan’s largest travel agencies within their Australian Head Office and have stayed at a fair share of hotels within Japan. When booking Moxy Tokyo I was a little hesitant considering some of the reviews but thought I would give it a go and now I wish I had booked this property for my whole Tokyo stay!! From the moment you arrive at the front door you can feel your in for a unique experience, unlike anything I’ve seen in Japan before! Check in is completed at the bar by extremely friendly staff which are either Japanese or foreigners so no need to worry about a language barrier! Within the same area there is also a large lounge with some hip music playing and various old school games laying around the tables, the also offer daily events that interact with staff or fellow guests!On the opposite side to this there is a library / meeting room for a quieter hang out space but personally I enjoyed sitting in the lounge to chill out with some loud music whilst working away!The rooms are made to feel quiet large due to the unnecessary items being hang on the wall such as a table, chair, luggage rack etc. The bathroom has the largest walk in shower I’ve seen in Tokyo for a long time with the most strongest hot water, something that’s hard to come by in hotels!!Now let’s go to the bed! Anyone that has travelled Japan a lot comes to expect a hard rock, but not at Moxy!!! The sleep I had last night was like sleeping on a cloud with the most softest pillows, I only wish I didn’t have business meetings today so that I could of slept longer!! The only negative of the room is there is no fridge but it honestly doesn’t matter considering there is a mini stop and 7/11 adjacent to the hotel.The location is only a short walk to Kinshicho station which provides easy access to pretty much everywhere within Tokyo. Some maybe worried about the location being within a red light district but honestly there’s nothing to worry about, some hotels in Shinjuku would be in a worse location!! Finally a big high five to the Blonde woman (Sorry I couldn’t see a name badge) who I am guessing is the manager. She made sure to acknowledge every person she came in contact with, along with wishing myself to have a good day! This is something I completely didn’t expect and it was so nice to feel genuine service!! If your looking for a 5 Star boring luxury experience then this hotel isn’t for you, but if your after an exciting enjoyable experience give this property and crew a go, I promise you won’t be disappointed!!!

My Moxy Kinshicho experience was so fun. The staff was very helpful and friendly, especially Khaleel, who became my friend. The hotel has everything you need for a stay in Tokyo and you will for sure meet some cool people when you're there:)

The Moxy in Kinshicho is well located just a couple of blocks from Kinshicho train/subway station. It's surrounded by restaurants and shops and is one subway stop from the SkyTree in Sumida.Great staff, good breakfast, and a quirky collection of parlor games offered a place to unwind.When we return to Tokyo, we'll definitely stay at the Moxy!

My husband and I came to Japan and spent one night, traveled the country, then came back for three more nights. They were very kind to store our bags at no charge. The Moxy Hotels have been taken under the wing of the Marriott family. Only three as of now-Tokyo, Osaka. and Malaysia. They are planning many more. It is located near the train station, which is very convenient. The staff is amazing and helpful. You can include breakfast if you like in the room price. The new hotel has awesome rooms, gym, laundry room and a fun bar to keep you entertained. Way to go Marriott and Moxy--outside the box!

This hotel is exactly as advertised - a hip, simple decor and vibe for an excellent price. It is virtually brand new. The service was attentive and friendly. Breakfast buffet was fresh with a good variety.It is based along a "red light" street. Not that it is any way dangerous or inappropriate...simple several drinking hostess bars. But, walk a block in any directly and your are in a simple, sale, working-class neighbourhood.The train station is two blocks away. We were in Ginza in 25 minutes door-to-door.There is a really good and friendly simple Ramen place just across the street. Use the ticket machine but the owner does speak some English.

We stumbled upon the Moxy Hotel in Tokyo after spending a few nights in AirBnBs and one hotel in Tokyo that did not meet our expectations. We booked our reservation online and headed directly over to at least drop off our luggage until check out. When we first arrived we explained that we were switching hotels and the staff were able to find us a room for an early check in right away with little to no notice. The hotel had a great vibe and the staff were very helpful. Our room was fantastic, well designed, and had everything we needed. We decided to cancel our other reservations in Tokyo and stay at the Moxy for our last five days in Tokyo; not because of the location or fantastic amenities and design of the hotel, but because the staff made us feel so welcome. We were told we may have to switch rooms in order to stay the extended days, which was fine with us. However, the staff was able to reshuffle reservations and keep us in our first room for the full 5 nights.The staff are from all over the globe, and we had a chance to get to know some of them. We could really tell that they enjoyed their work and genuinely were interested in meeting us. We felt as though we were making friends at the hotel. My partner got sick and the operations manager, Anne D., went above and beyond in helping us out. Allowing me to make meals to bring back to my sick partner, helping me in getting the food to the room, and offering assistance in finding cold remedies/pharmacies etc. in the neighborhood. The next day she checked in on us to make sure he was feeling better. The staff/bartenders Kei, Jasmine, and a gentleman from Bali whose name I cannot remember, also were amazing. We discussed Japan, the US, and where they had been. They offered us suggestions on things to see in Tokyo, and they even learned how to make my favorite cocktail and always had one ready to go when I came in for a drink.Our next trip is to Spain, and Anne D. has told us that there is a Moxy in Barcelona. That is where we will be staying! The Moxy Tokyo's staff makes you feel as comfortable as if you were staying at a long time friend's house, while the hotel provides the upscale amenities of a 5-star hotel. Highly recommended!

First time staying at a Moxy. Loved how quirky and chic it was. We checked in at the bar, where they had drinks available throughout the stay. Breakfast was served every morning and they had a nice variety of items. The staff was very prompt and attentive throughout the entire stay. Also loved the game room and library in the lobby area. The only negative about the hotel is that it's far from many things. There's a train station a few blocks away, and some 7-11 type shops next to the hotel, but that's about it. That being said, it was a great atmosphere and value and I would stay here again.

I stayed at the Moxy in Tokyo for more than a week during my trip to Japan. I knew the Moxy concept and I knew what I could expect...from the moment I arrived to the moment I checked out the staff and the hotel went over and above my expectations!The place is nothing but cool and modern and extra clean, very close to the metro line and in a quiet area. The staff was super friendly and guest oriented always smiling and ready to help. I love the Moxy brand and I highly suggest staying here when in Tokyo for both business or leisure.

A group of friends decided to stay at this property for our trip to Tokyo. While the hotel is relatively new (opened in Nov 2017) and the initial reviews were mixed, I have to say that we had an absolutely great time at this hotel for the 4 nights we were here. The place had such a neat vibe. It smelled amazing in the lobby, the check in counter was at the bar (which happens to be open 24/7). Breakfast was amazing. There's board games and a foosball table in the lobby. All the gym equipment was new. We stayed in standard rooms, and the rooms were surprisingly spacious for a hotel in Japan. As an SPG member that usually stays at SPG properties, it honestly felt like I was staying at a smaller, more homely W hotel, when looking at the modern decor and design. Service from everyone I interacted with was fantastic, with a special shout out to Khalif who gave us some great local food recommendations. While the location is in a bit of a red light district, the girls in our group felt safe walking alone at night (it is Japan after all), and the hotel is a 5 min walk from a major JR rail train station. Overall, I was pleasantly surprised by our stay and I definitely want to experience other Moxy hotels in the future. I would definitely stay at Moxy Tokyo again.

I had a change in travel plans and ended up spending an unscheduled night in Tokyo. I have stayed in many different hotels and areas in Tokyo, but was curious to see what Marriott was offering at the MOXY. Although very different from other hotels in Japan and other Marriotts, I was very pleased with my experience there. From the time I entered the hotel, I was greeted by two friendly and enthusiastic team members; Asami san and Maiko san. I have a firm belief that if employees enjoy working in a place, the customers will enjoy their experience. I had a very interesting conversation with the Director of Operations, Anne (who was ready available and very visible) who helped me to understand some of the concepts and challenges that they have been experiencing since opening this MOXY in Tokyp My room at the MOXY was larger than other hotel rooms in Tokyo, very clean with a comfortable bed and bathroom. The amenities were at a minimum, but still able to provide everything I needed for my stay. I had many opportunities to smile while I was there and would happily stay there again, if the opportunity presents it self. One of the only areas to suggest improvement would be the size of the large latte, (needs to be bigger ;>)

This hotel was great. I was traveling with a 12 yr old and we had a great time. The games were fun. And the atmosphere super inviting. One morning when we were tired we opted to hand in the lobby and play 1980's Super Mario and Uno. The room was amazing and clean. The shower was one of the best I have seen in a hotel. It is equipped with shower gel and conditioning shampoo. The amenities kit was great and more then I expected. It has a toothbrush / toothpaste /hair brush / file / hair tie / ect. And the beds were very comfortable. The location was across the street from a market as well as a 7 11. and is only about 5 min to the train station. Which had some great places to eat upstairs. I asked for a late check out and the crew gate me up until 4pm.....which was amazing. Also, they had safes and lockers that are right by the elevator. Some large enough to store luggage in. They were really convienent and appreciated. Overall between the excellent staff and hotel I would love to stay again......

If you're looking for typical, formal Japanese service this hotel will not be for you. There are no staff in white gloves popping out to grab your bags or open doors for you at this property. Staff, however, are incredibly helpful and I enjoyed the friendly, more casual service.The room was fantastic, and probably the best laid out one I have seen in Japan. It didn't have a closet, but I found using the wall pegs hanging clothes to be far more convenient. Bed was very comfortable. Bathroom was great. Room was considerably larger than those found in typical, more expensive Japanese properties.The hotel's breakfast buffet had western options that tasted far better than those I have found at expensive Japanese hotels. The dining area is nice, busy, social and informal--just the way I like it. Again, if you want white glove service, look elsewhere. Staff worked very hard and did a great job of keeping things stocked and fresh.The hotel has a gym that is free of charge to use. This, in my experience, is unusual in Japan. Another real convenience is the hotel's coin laundry area--spotlessly clean, and simple to use.The property's location is convenient. There are plenty of stores and restaurants in the area, but if you aren't exactly right in the middle of things where Tokyo's shopping or tourist attractions are concerned. JR Kinshicho station is about a 5-minute walk from the hotel, so getting around is easy.If you want to stay in the middle of Shibuya, Shinjuku or Ginza, you'll pay a lot more for a smaller, less comfortable room with far fewer conveniences. If you enjoy a decent sized, very comfortable room in a hotel that is more fun, has great staff service and far more conveniences despite being slightly out of the way you should consider the Moxy. I enjoyed it and will stay here again.

Clean rooms, pleasant helpful and supportive staff (especially the Manager Anne), convenient location, and trendy/hip feel to the whole place. Personally, I'd love to stay again especially as it's very near the train as well as shopping and some lovely restaurants. I've stayed a the range of hotels in Tokyo as well as around the world; if you're seeking somewhere fun and a bit different while your plans bring you to Tokyo, I'd suggest considering the Moxy... one word AWESOME :-)))

Few days ago I had to do a quick in and out trip to Tokyo, I wanted somewhere I am familiar and not too expensive. Although I didn’t have a good experience last time I was here I decided to give it a try again. I can honestly say that They has improved a lot and much more flexible and much better in service. The young lady that check me in used to work for Conrad she was sweet and very helpful. The room was very clean and the only bad thing is the folding table was too small to work with if you are here on business. The breakfast is included this time and better but make sure you go before the Chinese tour group or after. They are like a tornado, they swear up all the food in a minutes so you have to wait. The noodles is a bit too sweet for my taste and it’s Vietnamese Pho. I wish they would provide ramen instead but that is just me. A very happy experience the second time around. I will definitely come back to this hotel.

I am a Marriott guy. I stay at Marriott properties whenever possible. It's about consistency and perks, obviously. The motivations that led me to stay at this property in Tokyo were the same ones that led me to stay at the Moxy in Manhattan back in the Fall. Fortunately, this property is much better than the one in NYC. I almost didn't stay here because of how bad the New York experience was, but this one was all right. Considering that breakfast was included here (basically mandatory for a Tokyo hotel in this price range) unlike my awful NYC experience was already a point in this Moxy's favour. The room was big for this price range in Tokyo, which is good. The washroom was well equipped. It is not a Japanese unit bath, which is good. I was looking for a hotel that offered that. Even some of the "higher end" Marriotts in Tokyo have unit baths, so a modern offering was welcome. But the positives extended beyond that. The linens were what I would expect from any hotel (much less a Marriott) in that they were 100% cotton (the linens in NYC were a poor poly/cotton blend which made for a poor experience). The shower water pressure was excellent. The toiletries on offer were excellent.I also had a great chat with the staff in both English and Japanese. They even have some non-Japanese staff on rotation. Be warned that this location is not exactly family friendly. If you are oblivious to what is going on around you, or you return to your hotel before nighttime its fine, but otherwise know that this is essentially an active red light district. It's as safe as anywhere else in Japan, basically, but it's still worth mentioning. I would personally not stay here if I was on business, opting instead for something with a more formal feel (and a desk in the room) but it was just fine for my 4-day vacation getaway. However, as I have already alluded to, it was infinitely better than the same brand experience I had in NYC (at 2-3x the price) a few months earlier.My overall recommendation is to consider this property, even if you have an aversion to the brand thanks to the poor experience in NYC (or elsewhere). If you are not a Marriott Gold or Platinum member you will enjoy basically the same experience as I did since they offer nothing in the way of upgrades or lounged, etc. If you are a status member then late checkout etc. still apply. If you are budget conscious and want a Western name-brand hotel you can't go wrong, but if you are budget conscious I would suggest a Japanese brand such as APA or 'The b Hotel' by Isshin instead.

First time at a Moxy Hotel and was beyond impressed. The location was great and most importantly the Hotel was fun with a great vibe. The staff is great — very fun and attentive. Had everything — great breakfast and bar. Rooms were great, internet very fast and reliable. Fitness Center was great. Great value for money.

I made a booking about 1.5 month ago for my stay in early April 5-10, I'm seeking for some concierge help with some restaurant reservations which required booking in advance I sent emails a few times to reservations and general email address after I made my room reservation with all needed information. I've been waiting for their reply for more than a month still haven't heard anything from them. I'm so frustrated, coz some of the omakase restaurant got limited seats. I don't speak Japanese, that's why I book big chain hotels for concierge service. I'm a bit disappointed since I used to work in Marriott group as well. I hope someone read this message could get in touch with me please

We spent here 2 nights and we will come back for sure - close to the entertainment district ( but you don't have to worry) and good located. The breakfast was very nice, the rooms cozy and clean and the prices cheap. The staff was super nice and friendly ... We got a welcome drink and from day 2 they greeted us by our names. Thank you moxy, it was a pleasure

At first sight checking in ( at the main bar ) seemed odd. It is a different kind of hotel - community hip-like and very friendly ! I got a room ( 1008 ), strongly recommend this room ( bigger, quieter, and easy to walk to ). The breakfast and deli service is good. Laundry downstairs a plus. The overall view of the lobby lounge and deco is home hip-based. A 24-hr convenience store facing the entrance. And easy walkable to two subway stations. The only comment is outside at weekends, many men’s nightclubs and bars around. A bit noisy at night. The location of this hotel is near SkyTree.

I’ve stayed at the Moxy for a total of 10 nights and i have really enjoyed my stay! Yes it is minimalistic but the rooms are clean and functional just like the photos, and has everything you need. The hotel is a short walk from Kinshico station, from which you can get to most places really easily, and the staff, especially the ones working the nights, have been awesome! People complaining about music in the reviews need to stop being so boring and have some fun, its not too loud at all and always has a great vibe in the main lobby area with plenty of cool toys and games to keep you busy if you’re looking for something to do. If you want a boring dead hotel then look elsewhere.I would say ignore the stupid negative comments from people who expect everything on a plate, this is a great hotel and deserves much better reviews than it has gotten and i would absolutely stay here again and recommend it to anyone considering it.Want to thank Deexhit on the front desk especially as he has always been super friendly and professional. Was a pleasure to meet you and thank you for making our stay even better!

We have stayed at a number of Moxy Hotels and were familiar with the concept of minimal service and the encouragement of mingling/interactions in the lobby. However, one night we wanted to get a drink at the bar in the lobby and discovered we had to pay to get into the lobby due to an event the hotel was hosting. We didn’t appreciate access being denied. The music was so loud that we heard it in our room. There was also no consideration given despite Platinum status. There was a sign in the lobby saying “Don’t Look our Guests in the Eye.” Perhaps that is cultural but we found it disturbing.

You're in Tokyo, expect small rooms unless you are willing to spend a fortune. The rate for the Tokyo Moxy and the room size is to be expected.Room was very clean, modern and well thought out. Lots of hot water and lots of water pressure. Clean sheets and bedding. Though the bed was a bit too soft for my liking. Window could have been better, some noise does come through from the street.The entire building is well designed. Gym has treadmills, steppers, light dumbbells and some rubber band stuff. if you're a serious gym rat, don't waste your time. Staff were friendly and helpful.Check in is at the bar.Never tried any of the food, I'm out most of the day.Excellent WIFI.You are a 5 minute walk, from the Kinshicho Metro station, on the Sobu line. At the station take the south exit, turn right, first street, about 50' west of Starbucks, walk directly south about two blocks. Square grey building.They almost try too hard to be trendy, but I will stay here again.

My family and I loved this hotel. The edgy interior design was great. Breakfasts were fantastic - really tasty noodles, yoghurt with muesli (that was really tasty too) and other options were simple but we always looked forward to it. As Platinum members we were very well looked after by the hotel staff. And little things like the laundromat in the basement were helpful. All round the hotel were lots of small bars and restaurants with authentic cuisine. It's also got some girly bars very close by, which wasn't quite what my family was looking for, but they didn't disturb us and we didn't disturb them... our only gripe was that twice, room service forgot to refresh our rooms. However reception was very quick to help out with extra water and toilet rolls when we called down to request them. Would certainly like to stay here again

I have been using Marriott around the world for the past 15 to 20 years. I wanted to try this new brand in Tokyo, Japan. This was not the hotel for me. While I see that it is meant for the budget young customer, there are some aspects that that i can never accept. Check in was done at the bar on a Saturday with a DJ and very loud music. I could not hear what the associates were saying. The rooms are very small which was OK as per the style of the hotel but no closets you will need to hand your clothes on the wall as was a small table, chair, etc. There is no room for more than a small carry on. Breakfast was awful. Food was scarce and felt like you were lining up for a "MASH" type food on a metal plate. On one of the choices you ca get was a tablespoon of scrambled egg, mashes potatoes, tablespoon of spinach and two small sausage links and if you are a bit late you get only one. For the 3 nights we were there, sliced bread was as rare as gold. On checking out they could store aure larger bags, but was asked to use the lockers for the smaller bags.While the idea of a hostel type hotel with laundry in the basement, ironing room in each floor, is good there are some aspects of this brands that I will never accept.

The Moxy got it right for young/fun travelers. Cool lobby and bar... Room was small (though not bad for Tokyo) but clean, great queen bed and excellent bathroom. Shower was hot with solid pressure. As a platinum Marriott guest, I really appreciated that they didn't skimp on the member benefits and offered a unique free breakfast (loved the ramen bar) and plenty of free drink perks. Staff is also young, fun and helpful... Self serve laundry, solid gym are good for tourist trips...Location is near a train station with adequate connectivity. Yes there are some local bars that are more colorful than usual, a part of Tokyo we may not have seen... But still very clean and safe. Minor ways to improve: a couple English television channels would be nice... And for some reason they run an add for Moxy hotels on loop on all other TVs that looks like it was made by some corporate execs at Marriott based on results from a millennial focus group... (Put hashtags in front of everything and the kids will think we are cool) All in all, highly recommended, great stay...

What a great hotel, not too big, rooms are small but well appointed and very functional. The staff is absolutely awesome, I just can’t say enough how much we enjoyed our 5 day stay at The Moxy Tokyo Kinshicho.Also close to Subway and Trains.

The hotel is a few blocks away from the train station. The walk to/from the hotel is manageable. Being new, not a lot of people know where it is. Even taxi drivers. So best to map it and get directions before going to the hotel. They don’t have a traditional check-in counter/reception. You’d check in at the bar!!! The common area at the ground floor was nicely decorated and encourages social interaction. The roons were functionally decorated with a modern industrial feel. Loved the decors throughout the hotel. On the downside, there’s no executive lounge or free breakfast for elite marriott members. Although there’s a lot of restaurants around the area, and two convenience stores across the hotel. WiFi was a little slow. Good thing i rented a WiFi hotspot from the airport. And rooms were a little cramped. Although, we were given a corner room with a stunning view of Tokyo’s skytree and its surrounding skyscrapers!!! Awesome stay a this new hotel in tokyo.

I’ve never stayed at a Moxy brand hotel before but I love it. I’ve stayed at a lot of boutique hotels and actually prefer them over he standard “chain” type hotels (even though I know this is part of the Marriott group) because they have more character and charm.With that being said, the hotel far exceeded my expectations especially for the price. The beds were just as comfortable as your usual Marriott bed. The staff is super friendly and nice. They were very accommodating and personable. I think that’s what I have liked the most. The decor is really cute and I love it. The beds were comfortable and the room layout is enough for my travel needs. I saw on other review sites that some people had issues with the location because it is in the “red light district.” They must be very conservative people because the occasional doormen/ladies standing in doorways trying to bring in customers didn’t bother me at all and I never felt a sense of danger walking there. It is in a brightly lit area. I’m a woman in my late 30s and I never felt in danger. I even came home late past midnight on some nights and I still didn’t have any issues or feel I was in a dangerous situation. Definitely will be back here because of it has everything I need/want in a hotel and at the price point I want. The laundry downstairs was also a huge plus as were the staff. They were all so knowledgeable and nice and down to earth. Yes, I understand the frustrations of Marriott members who expect certain perks they usually get, but they should read the description and stay at the other Marriott in Shinagawa if they want their perks. To judge this hotel because it is a Moxy brand/line with limited perks versus a Marriott/Marriott just isn’t fair.

It's hard to find. That 3-4-2 address is worthless. The JR Rail Pass office at the airport told us to take the Rapid JR line on (I think) track 2 to Kinshicho station, direct. No change or transfer. That way we avoided the main Tokyo station and a transfer. When you leave the station from the South exit, cross that main street, walk 1/2 block to the right and then turn left. Walk two blocks and the Moxy will be on the far corner. My friend had it all on the GPS on his phone. It is a 20-minute walk, not 10. You check in at the bar! On duty was Kei (pronounced K) who went to high school in Alabama. Good English! The hotel is new. Everything is new. The new pillows need to be worn down a bit. Our twin beds struck me as being 3/4 beds, which existed in the 1950s. Wider than a twin but narrower than a double. They do not use fitted sheets. The bottom sheet was small and the top sheet was big, making for a messy bed. I asked for additional bed covers. Never got them. The key-making machine was broken for two days. Once the machine was repaired, they could not find me in the computer by room number. They demanded way too much ID from me. The neighborhood is full of "girlie" clubs, hostess clubs. "Touts" on the sidewalks. 7-11 is across the street. The "rain" shower is in a big glass "closet" which holds in the steam. Learn the controls! Breakfast is a noodle menu. We went to Komida's Coffee, 2nd floor, on that main street facing the south wall of the Kinshicho station. We went four times! No Marriott points are earned here.

Funky and modern hotel. It is a proper built hotel under the American brand. The room is spacious not like the typical Japanese hotel room. First floor there is bar plus reception .. each staff was so friendly and cute! Room 606 has twin beds! I will definitely come back! Only 5 minutes walk from the JR station. The TV is so good!

My husband and I stayed at the Moxy hotel for 8 nights in November. The hotel is situated few minutes from Kinshicho station. Great location for the metro and jr east line. Which was very handy for us as we had bought the JR rail pass. Our room was on the 9th floor, beds were very comfortable and shower was amazing. Despite not having any wardrobes the wall hangers were more than adequate. Breakfast was included in our room rate. They provided variety of pastries, bread, yoghurts, noodles etc. The kitchen staff were always very obliging nothing was to much trouble for them. The staff couldn’t do enough for us, we were looking for halal restaurants and Keisuke at the front desk went out of his way to call several restaurants for us and do print outs of maps etc.’ My husband was not feeling very well for few days and Christopher at front desk enquired everyday on how we were doing and if we required any assistance. Loved the lounge area it was so warm and welcoming. We loved the whole new concept of this hotel! Definitely would go back again. On our last day Keisuke and Dixit from front desk both came to wave us off in our taxi. We would highly recommend this fun, quirky hotel. All the best to the Staff.

My husband and I traveled to Tokyo in November and stayed at the MOXY. I had already read the previous reviews and done my research so I was prepared for the experience - which could be very different if you didn't do so. The hotel is a short 10 minute walk from the train station (Kinshicho) and was actually a direct train ride from NRT airport. It was about an hour and a half train ride. Actually, the train system is Tokyo is wonderful and can basically get you anywhere you need to go. The Kinshicho station was one of the major stops. Upon arrival at the hotel, you have to check in at the bar. That didn't bother us at all as we still received the same great service we usually receive from Marriott. The area around the bar is laid out with games and other entertainment and is also connected to the sit down food area. We didn't eat in the hotel, so I can't really comment on the food offerings. However, the food appeared to be standard Japanese style offerings, with some sprinklings of conventional breads, pastries and yogurts.Our room was located on the 9th floor. I was surprised to see that we had a wonderful unobstructed view of the Tokyo Skytree from there. That was an unexpected treat. The room was laid out nicely, with a very comfortable bed. I'm not sure if the room was considered big or small by Tokyo standards, as this was my first visit, but it definitely served its purpose - which was minimal furnishings (no closet, but hooks on the wall to hang belongings and a table that could be hung on the wall when not in use to avoid taking up space). As others have stated, there is no refrigerator or safe in the room. That can potentially be a downside if you are used to having these items. However, we made it through without a problem. The bathroom was really nice, had adequate space and a wonderful shower and toilet.The area surrounding the hotel has a few convenient stores a number of bars and restaurants. As others have stated, it did appear to be a red light district at night, but it was nothing that would make you feel unsafe. In fact, we never had any issue with being approached and had no problem walking around at any time of night.All in all, we had a wonderful time at the MOXY and really liked the new concept hotel. The staff was wonderful, always helpful and greeted us with a smile. We would definitely stay here again if we were ever to return to Tokyo.

review_body: I liked this hotel for a single night visit. Very spartan rooms that are new, clean, and efficient. No closets in the room I had. HINT: Look on the wall for extra chairs and such...The check in is at the bar which may or may not be convenient for some, but its kind of fun. The staff and services are "Japanese Rigid" but they were fun and tried to be as hip as those cats could be.One observation is that the crowd they seem to be targeting, the 20-30 YO's are not the majority of guests there. Most had silver tops and a grumpy I've traveled too much look in their eye. Something tells me the rates they would have to charge to attract that crowd is a real bargain for the road warriors in Tokyo. So there is that....I cant say much about the area as I walked out the south entrance of the train station. Took a right, walked to the light, crossed the street, and strolled up two blocks to the hotel tugging luggage and that was that. (Hey maybe it was convenient now that I think about it) I caught an early morning taxi to another spot and did not really look back.All and all a nice stay and worth a second visit on my part, and not just for the better than decent price.

I recently stayed at this property for a period of approximately two weeks. It was my first stay at a Moxy property. I am a Tokyo resident and have stayed in numerous properties in and around Toyko. I am a Marriott Platinum member, so write this review from that perspective. With hesitation and depending on my travel situation, I would stay at this property again.This is Marriot’s newest foray into the Tokyo hotel market, having just opened on 1 November. It definitely still had that new hotel smell. For the uninitiated, Moxy is Marriott’s pairing with Swedish furniture marker IKEA in an effort to target the millennial, hipster travel market. Once you take one step onto the property, you can definitely feel that is the case. Location: The property is located a few minutes’ walk from Kinshicho Station, a major train station that services both JR and Metro train lines. It is convenient to getting anywhere in Tokyo, and just a few stops away from popular areas like Akihabara. There are plenty of restaurants nearby the station, and directly next to the property. There are two convenience stores directly adjacent to the hotel, along with a dry cleaners a short walk down the road (ask a Japanese staff member). As a prior resident of Tokyo, I had never been to Kinshicho before, but found that there was plenty to do in the evening after returning to the hotel. The area nearby the hotel does feature an abundance of bars and night life spots designed to attract a male crowd, and you may be asked while walking in the evening if you are interested in massage services (happened several times to me). Just say no and keep walking, you really aren’t in any danger in this neighborhood. Overall, a great location for all intents and purposes.Facilities: The hotel features a basement gym with all new equipment. I made use of the treadmill a couple of times while staying there. It also has a machine piece that lets you do pull ups, has a punching bag, etc. There is also a (huge plus) laundry room in basement with very reasonable prices. The washing machines dispense their own detergent directly into the laundry load, so there is no need to worry about that. The wash was 300 JPY per load, and the dryer was 100 JPY per 30 minutes. I recommend 60 minutes for an average size load, as my clothes tended to still be slightly damp after an hour of drying. This was a great plus for those staying more than a few days. The first floor features a very ‘hipster’ lounge set up with open seating, games on the tables, and a foosball machine. There is also a 24-hour bar (!) with reasonably priced drinks (small beer was 480 JPY). The intent seemed to be to get guests to mix and socialize with each other. I tended not to have any energy at the end of the day for this, but it seemed like there were always a few people milling around.Rooms: Rooms are a bit smaller compared to your average tourist hotel in Tokyo. They get around this a bit by making all of the furniture hangable. It took me a minute to realize it upon entering the room, but there are pegs along the wall which features a collapsible desk, chairs, and luggage rack. If you don’t need them, then you don’t have to use them and they don’t take up space. The bathroom featured a Japanese style bidet and a strong, hot shower. The thought the bed was very comfortable, and the internet was fast and dependable. The air circulation on the floor and in the room seemed a little weak, but maybe that is something they could tweak as they adjust past their opening. You won’t get much of a view from your room as it is surrounded mostly by buildings. I had a look into a residential building within feet of my window, so mostly kept my curtain closed. Two negatives to the rooms. The biggest negative is that the rooms do not have a safe in them. I have not seen this in a long while. They definitely need to put small safes in the room, and have space to do so. This was an inconvenience for me during my stay. There was also no refrigerator, which was frustrating. If you don’t plan on spending loads of time in your room (which you shouldn’t when touring in Tokyo), then the room will mostly meet your needs (minus the safe and fridge).Staff: Friendly and helpful. They seemed to be the strongest part of the property. They definitely had that new hotel opening energy to them. There are English speaking staff on the clock, so if you find yourself having trouble communicating with one of the Japanese staff, just ask for a native speaker and you should be ok.Room Rate: You will definitely find that the room rates at this hotel are much cheaper than what you will find at other major hotel lines in Tokyo – almost as much as half. I think they get by on this due to the hotel's location, reduction in some amenities, and perhaps lower staffing. They also provide almost no benefits to Marriott status members. I was provided points upon check-in and a welcome drink token. No breakfast whatsoever, lounge, etc. I was told this upon check-in, and told that a daily noodle breakfast would cost 1,300 JPY. Not being a noodle breakfast guy, I did not try the noodle bar breakfast during my stay.Negatives: Being a Marriot Platinum member and not gaining any tangible benefit during my stay was a negative for me at this property. If I am traveling on my own dime and understand what I am walking into, then maybe I stay here to save a few dollars. If your budget allows more for lodging, then you will want to consider other Marriott properties in Tokyo which provide Platinum benefits. I probably would only stay here again if not traveling on business. Also, during my stay, they apparently had a grand opening party. There was no notice provided to me (either upon check-in or via notification to my room). I came back one night and the lounge had turned into a club with loud music, a DJ, and wrist bands being put on at the door. I didn’t see any notification of what was happening, so I assumed it was a private party of some sort. I found out afterwards that it was a grand opening party, and was a bit confused why no notification had been provided. Another negative is the elevators on each floor. If you have a room anywhere near the elevator, you will hear the constant dinging for when the elevator comes to your floor. They should find a way to reduce the volume, or cancel the audible notification if at all possible. I was woken up a few times by this elevator noise in the mornings. Also, I think they could do more with their kitchen and food menu. I took a glance at it and nothing sounded remotely appetizing to me. At least, nothing that would dissuade me from walking across the street to grab something from the convenience store. The food items all seemed to be frozen items that they would simply heat up and serve (vice freshly preparing in a kitchen by a cook staff). The staff was also unable to provide an electric outlet adaptor upon request (Japanese plugs do not use a ground, and you have to have a two-prong adaptor to use three-prong plugs). I was told to visit an electronics store next to the station to buy my own. One last note is the check-out receipt. For some reason (first time I have seen it done this way at a hotel in Tokyo), they add a lump sum consumption tax and also lump sum accommodation tax on the last day of the stay (vice showing the amount for each day during the stay). This can make it confusing for business travelers trying to reconcile their charges with their accounting departments. Each day’s total charge should be clearly delineated with all charges and taxes.Overall, the property is a good value for what you pay, and is a good value for a Tokyo hotel. For those used to extra hotel amenities, or Marriot status members who are accustomed to the usual perks, this property will not completely satisfy you. I expect the property will improve once they work out a few kinks from their recent opening.

Stayed at this place in the middle of November 2017 using points for a couple of nights. I used a bus from Haneda airport to the Kinshicho train station which took only 30 minutes.The walk from the train station to the hotel was no more than 10 minutes. Walking to the hotel, though, would pass you through a red light district type area.The touts never bothered me and still felt safe walking through the neighborhood at night.The check in area looked like a bar and there's no actual signage to tell you otherwise except for directions once you enter the building. Check in was a breeze and I was provided a welcome drink which was some sort of tart grapefruit type drink. I was also provided with a drink voucher as recognition of my frequency status. The room was pretty much your average Japanese business hotel type with no closet. The down side of the room was that you had to hang your clothes on the wall were there was a table and chair also hanging. Another down side was that there was no mini fridge to keep your drinks or snacks should you decide to bring back to the hotel room. The bathroom only had a stand up shower. I didn't have a chance to check out the eating options in the lobby. There were plenty of eating options within walking distance of the area. Went out during the day to due some sightseeing and was suprised to see the card to I had inserted into the slot to turn on the room power had been taken. Though it says to insert the hotel key card, I inserted a different card. Luckily, housekeeping was just next door and ask for the card. Sure enough, he had it in his pocket. That evening, as I was about to shower, I come to find out that my toothbrush and razor had been thrown away. Why would housekeeping throw this away?!?! Even if I used the provided amenities that was in the bathroom, you still don't throw things away unless I'm checking out that day!!! I'm returning in January to watch the Sumo tournament and I really wanted to stay at this hotel again since it's only 1 train stop away from the Kokugikan. Unfortunately, after this experience, I will not be staying here again. This is a brand new hotel but the idea that my things were thrown away was enough to make me not want to return. I have never rated a Marriott branded hotel so low, but this one was earned.

First off, let me say that normally I stay in the Shinagawa area, but saw that the Moxy just opened and that it is 10 minutes walk from my meetings (a huge plus to start off with for me). tj k's comments (one start) about the property are very accurate: the red light district (I noticed when I left the hotel at 4:30 in the morning for a week day business meeting, but didn't feel unsafe or even bothered...no one was looking at me), everything revolving around the hotel bar (it is a front desk on one side and a bar on the other), free drink (they gave you a casino chip, which I just kept as a momento), no free breakfast, tight rooms (but not bad by Japanese standards), minimalist features (no closet, just dowels jutting out of the wall with only two hangers...also a table, chair hanging from the same dowels), no real Marriott status recognition beyond a free drink (insert joke if you read tj k's overview), insanely loud and pulsing music at night in the lobby (I was on a high floor, so not sure what it would be like on the 2nd level), questionable room cleaning timing (I returned at 5pm and they had just started cleaning my room), etc. With that all being said, I still liked it and the price was very reasonable for a property that provides Marriott Rewards points. The property just opened in early November, so some things should sort themselves out (grapefruit juice, cleaning crew...also not having insurance for the bike rentals that are sitting in the entrance way), so for me, it would be worth returning. Still, I can understand why others would absolutely hate the place.

We travelled as a group of four. We are women in our mid - 40's from Canada.The hotel was conveniently located and easy to find, a 7 minute walk from the train station.The whole approach is refreshing and fun! The staff were great! They went out of their way to accommodate us and to make us feel welcome. Considering the hotel opened less than two weeks ago, and some of the staff are still training, they did their best to welcome us. The majority of the staff spoke English. I would highly suggest you try it out. It is wonderful to live like you are younger all over again.Our rate included breakfast and there was a nice assortment of coffee, tea, treats, yogurts and traditional Japanese Soup.The rooms were very comfortable and clean. The washroom, especially the shower, was excellent. You'll have to check out the electronic toilet. The beds were so comfortable. The rooms are small but serve the purpose and if you want to chill there is a nice size TV.The common space, lounge, bar and other areas are very cool. Lot of attention to detail. If you come from abroad, "foreigner" you will enjoy this new and refreshing approach to traditional hotels. It is obvious that this hotel is reaching out to the younger 30+ international client. Don't be scared to try something new. Despite the hotel being in the Red-light District, it is super safe. You only notice the activity at night. This being said, we walked around at all hours and never felt scared or threatened. After all this is Japan and security is taken seriously.You won't find the traditional slippers and robes found at other Japanese hotels but you will experience a new approach.Enjoy and tell your friends! We loved it!

The front desk staff was particularly helpful with getting around and finding things to do, and they had fresh squeezed OJ. Also it's int he heart of a night life scene. This was a win.

Stayed here the first night the hotel opened at the end of my 2-week trip through Tokyo. First impression: casual, welcoming and stylish. The staff is incredibly friendly, and clearly excited to be here with the grand opening. There is a lot of interesting stuff to look at and the place seems designed for Instagramming millennials. I have to keep reminding myself that MOXY is a Marriott brand, because it feels like a big departure from their usual hotels. Things I loved: room design, incredibly comfortable beds, best shower I've ever experienced (!!!). The staff speaks excellent English and are so friendly (can't say that enough). The gym has great equipment and is a step up from other hotels I've stayed in. The "Pimp My Noodles" station in the lobby is fun and delicious. Things I didn't love: neighborhood seems a bit seedy at night (but coming from San Francisco, this is a walk in the park). You definitely get a more real experience of Tokyo here, and you can't beat the location to the metro and JR line, super convenient, so I think that this ends up being a wash. The rooms don't have a closet and are a bit small. This isn't a huge deal for me, as I packed light, but something you may want to plan for. There are free lockers in the lobby to hold extra baggage.One last thing I'd call out is that despite the small room size, it feels well thought out and stylish with every amenity you can think of. To top it off, the lobby/bar is a great place to relax and hang out, playing good music, good views of the hood, and a bar, so there is a community feel here that I've not seen at a hotel before. I loved it!Definitely consider staying here if your travels take you through Tokyo.
